header.title: ftp

description.p: This module implements a client for file transfer according to a subset of the File Transfer Protocol (FTP), see RFC 959.
The FTP client always tries to use passive FTP mode and only resort to active FTP mode if this fails. This default behavior can be changed by start option mode.
An FTP client can be started in two ways. One is using the service_start function, the other is to start it directly as a standalone process using function open.
For a simple example of an FTP session, see FTP User's Guide.

In addition to the ordinary functions for receiving and sending files (see recv/2, recv/3, send/2, and send/3) there are functions for receiving remote files as binaries (see recv_bin/2) and for sending binaries to be stored as remote files (see send_bin/3).

A set of functions is provvided for sending and receiving contiguous parts of a file to be stored in a remote file. For send, see send_chunk_start/2, send_chunk/2, and send_chunk_end/1. For receive, see recv_chunk_start/2 and recv_chunk/).

The return values of the following functions depend much on the implementation of the FTP server at the remote host. In particular, the results from ls and nlist varies. Often real errors are not reported as errors by ls, even if, for example, a file or directory does not exist. nlist is usually more strict, but some implementations have the peculiar behaviour of responding with an error if the request is a listing of the contents of a directory that exists but is empty.

section.title: FTP CLIENT SERVICE START/STOP
section.p: The FTP client can be started and stopped dynamically in runtime by calling the ftp application API ftp:start_service(ServiceConfig) and ftp:stop_service(Pid).
The available configuration options are as follows:

item.p: Determines if the FTP communication is to be verbose or not.
With inet6fb4 the client behaves as before, that is, tries to use IPv6, and only if that does not work it uses IPv4).
Data connect time-out. The time the client waits for the server to connect to the data socket.

note.p: The callback is made by a middleman process, hence the file transfer is not affected by the code in the progress callback function. If the callback crashes, this is detected by the FTP connection process, which then prints an info-report and goes on as if the progress option was set to ignore.

section.p: The file transfer type is set to the default of the FTP server when the session is opened. This is usually ASCCI mode.
The current local working directory (compare lpwd/1) is set to the value reported by file:get_cwd/1, the wanted local directory.

The return value Pid is used as a reference to the newly created FTP client in all other functions, and they are to be called by the process that created the connection. The FTP client process monitors the process that created it and terminates if that process terminates.

section.title: DATA TYPES
section.p: The following type definitions are used by more than one function in the FTP client API:
pid() = identifier of an FTP connection
restriction_reason() = epath | efnamena | elogin | enotbinary - all restrictions are not always relevant to all functions
common_reason() = econn | eclosed | term() - some explanation of what went wrong

func.name: account(Pid, Account) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Specifies which account to use.

desc.p: Sets the account for an operation, if needed.

func.name: append(Pid, LocalFile) ->
append(Pid, LocalFile, RemoteFile) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Transfers a file to remote server, and appends it to Remotefile.

type.v: Reason = epath | elogin | etnospc | epnospc | efnamena | common_reason

desc.p: Transfers the file LocalFile to the remote server. If RemoteFile is specified, the name of the remote file that the file is appended to is set to RemoteFile, otherwise to LocalFile. If the file does not exists, it is created.

func.name: append_bin(Pid, Bin, RemoteFile) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Transfers a binary into a remote file.

desc.p: Transfers the binary Bin to the remote server and appends it to the file RemoteFile. If the file does not exist, it is created.

func.name: append_chunk(Pid, Bin) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Appends a chunk to the remote file.

desc.p: Transfers the chunk Bin to the remote server, which appends it to the file specified in the call to append_chunk_start/2.
For some errors, for example, file system full, it is necessary to call append_chunk_end to get the proper reason.

func.name: append_chunk_start(Pid, File) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Starts transfer of file chunks for appending to File.

desc.p: Starts the transfer of chunks for appending to the file File at the remote server. If the file does not exist, it is created.

func.name: append_chunk_end(Pid) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Stops transfer of chunks for appending.

desc.p: Stops transfer of chunks for appending to the remote server. The file at the remote server, specified in the call to append_chunk_start/2, is closed by the server.

func.name: cd(Pid, Dir) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Changes remote working directory.

desc.p: Changes the working directory at the remote server to Dir.

func.name: close(Pid) -> ok
func.fsummary: Ends the FTP session.

desc.p: Ends an FTP session, created using function open.

func.name: delete(Pid, File) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Deletes a file at the remote server.

desc.p: Deletes the file File at the remote server.

func.name: formaterror(Tag) -> string()
func.fsummary: Returns error diagnostics.

desc.p: Given an error return value {error, AtomReason}, this function returns a readable string describing the error.

func.name: lcd(Pid, Dir) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Changes local working directory.

desc.p: Changes the working directory to Dir for the local client.

func.name: lpwd(Pid) -> {ok, Dir}
func.fsummary: Gets local current working directory.

desc.p: Returns the current working directory at the local client.

func.name: ls(Pid) ->
ls(Pid, Pathname) -> {ok, Listing} | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: List of files.

desc.p: Returns a list of files in long format.
Pathname can be a directory, a group of files, or a file. The Pathname string can contain wildcards.
ls/1 implies the current remote directory of the user.
The format of Listing depends on the operating system. On UNIX, it is typically produced from the output of the ls -l shell command.

func.name: mkdir(Pid, Dir) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Creates a remote directory.

desc.p: Creates the directory Dir at the remote server.

func.name: nlist(Pid) ->
nlist(Pid, Pathname) -> {ok, Listing} | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: List of files.

desc.p: Returns a list of files in short format.
Pathname can be a directory, a group of files, or a file. The Pathname string can contain wildcards.
nlist/1 implies the current remote directory of the user.

The format of Listing is a stream of filenames where each filename is separated by <CRLF> or <NL>. Contrary to function ls, the purpose of nlist is to enable a program to process filename information automatically.

func.name: open(Host) -> {ok, Pid} | {error, Reason}
open(Host, Opts) -> {ok, Pid} | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Starts a standalone FTP client.

type.v: debug() = disable | debug | trace (default is disable)
open_option() = {ipfamily, ipfamily()} | {port, port()} | {mode, mode()} | {tls, tls_options()} | {timeout, timeout()} | {dtimeout, dtimeout()} | {progress, progress()}
ipfamily() = inet | inet6 | inet6fb4 (default is inet)
pogress() = ignore | {module(), function(), initial_data()} (default is ignore)

desc.p: Starts a standalone FTP client process (without the ftp service framework) and opens a session with the FTP server at Host.

If option {tls, tls_options()} is present, the FTP session is transported over tls (ftps, see RFC 4217). The list tls_options() can be empty. The function ssl:connect/3 is used for securing both the control connection and the data sessions.
A session opened in this way is closed using function close.

func.name: pwd(Pid) -> {ok, Dir} | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Gets the remote current working directory.

desc.p: Returns the current working directory at the remote server.

func.name: recv(Pid, RemoteFile) ->
recv(Pid, RemoteFile, LocalFile) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Transfers a file from remote server.

desc.p: Transfers the file RemoteFile from the remote server to the file system of the local client. If LocalFile is specified, the local file will be LocalFile, otherwise RemoteFile.
If the file write fails (for example, enospc), the command is aborted and {error, file_write_error_reason()} is returned. However, the file is not removed.

func.name: recv_bin(Pid, RemoteFile) -> {ok, Bin} | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Transfers a file from remote server as a binary.

desc.p: Transfers the file RemoteFile from the remote server and receives it as a binary.

func.name: recv_chunk_start(Pid, RemoteFile) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Starts chunk-reading of the remote file.

desc.p: Starts transfer of the file RemoteFile from the remote server.

func.name: recv_chunk(Pid) -> ok | {ok, Bin} | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Receives a chunk of the remote file.

desc.p: Receives a chunk of the remote file (RemoteFile of recv_chunk_start). The return values have the following meaning:

list.item: {ok, Bin} = just another chunk of the file.

func.name: rename(Pid, Old, New) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Renames a file at the remote server.

desc.p: Renames Old to New at the remote server.

func.name: rmdir(Pid, Dir) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Removes a remote directory.

desc.p: Removes directory Dir at the remote server.

func.name: send(Pid, LocalFile) ->
send(Pid, LocalFile, RemoteFile) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Transfers a file to the remote server.

desc.p: Transfers the file LocalFile to the remote server. If RemoteFile is specified, the name of the remote file is set to RemoteFile, otherwise to LocalFile.

func.name: send_bin(Pid, Bin, RemoteFile) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Transfers a binary into a remote file.

desc.p: Transfers the binary Bin into the file RemoteFile at the remote server.

func.name: send_chunk(Pid, Bin) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Writes a chunk to the remote file.

desc.p: Transfers the chunk Bin to the remote server, which writes it into the file specified in the call to send_chunk_start/2.
For some errors, for example, file system full, it is necessary to to call send_chunk_end to get the proper reason.

func.name: send_chunk_start(Pid, File) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Starts transfer of file chunks.

desc.p: Starts transfer of chunks into the file File at the remote server.

func.name: send_chunk_end(Pid) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Stops transfer of chunks.

desc.p: Stops transfer of chunks to the remote server. The file at the remote server, specified in the call to send_chunk_start/2 is closed by the server.

func.name: start_service(ServiceConfig) -> {ok, Pid} | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Dynamically starts an FTP session after the ftp application has been started.

desc.p: Dynamically starts an FTP session after the ftp application has been started.

note.p: As long as the ftp application is operational, the FTP sessions are supervised and can be soft code upgraded.

func.name: stop_service(Reference) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Stops an FTP session.

desc.p: Stops a started FTP session.

func.name: type(Pid, Type) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: Sets transfer type to asciior binary.

desc.p: Sets the file transfer type to ascii or binary. When an FTP session is opened, the default transfer type of the server is used, most often ascii, which is default according to RFC 959.

func.name: user(Pid, User, Password) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: User login.

desc.p: Performs login of User with Password.

func.name: user(Pid, User, Password, Account) -> ok | {error, Reason}
func.fsummary: User login.

desc.p: Performs login of User with Password to the account specified by Account.

func.name: quote(Pid, Command) -> [FTPLine]
func.fsummary: Sends an arbitrary FTP command.

note.p: The telnet end of line characters, from the FTP protocol definition, CRLF, for example, "\\r\\n" has been removed.

desc.p: Sends an arbitrary FTP command and returns verbatim a list of the lines sent back by the FTP server. This function is intended to give application accesses to FTP commands that are server-specific or that cannot be provided by this FTP client.

note.p: FTP commands requiring a data connection cannot be successfully issued with this function.

section.title: ERRORS
section.p: The possible error reasons and the corresponding diagnostic strings returned by formaterror/1 are as follows:

item.p: Synchronization error during chunk sending according to one of the following:

list.item: A call is made to send_chunk/2 or send_chunk_end/1 before a call to send_chunk_start/2.
A call has been made to another transfer function during chunk sending, that is, before a call to send_chunk_end/1.

item.p: Connection to the remote server is prematurely closed.
Host is not found, FTP server is not found, or connection is rejected by FTP server.
No such file or directory, or directory already exists, or permission denied.
Exceeded storage allocation (for current directory or dataset) [552].

section.p: file(3) filename(3) and J. Postel and J. Reynolds: File Transfer Protocol (RFC 959).
